text: 4. Inspiration comes from most things. I understand that inspiration for most good short films comes from one's own life experience, and from stories based on things that happened to you and subjects/emotions/situations you lived and understand well. I think the same applies for illustration - chances are you're going to find your style and be really good when you're doing your own thing, with the limitations you have and acknowledge, instead of trying to mimick someone's style. It might take time, but I believe it's worth it.

Also, at least the I see it, inspiration for animation comes from anywhere but animation itself. Of course I like to watch animation and see other people's work, but when you try to do something like some animation you saw, it most likely will look like some (that one) animation/drawing.

5. There are several books on animation techniques by various super talented animators, but if you had to pick one it'd be The Animator's Survival Kit by Richard Williams. It really has all the basics and also complex stuff, explained with drawing the best way you can get. It's based on drawings but it applies to any technique you'd choose to animate.
Aaron Blaise animated for Disney and he has a channel on YouTube with a lot of resources for free.

One good way to do it is you pick a film or character you like, then search online what studio/animator animated that particular character and look for their blog/Instagram. You'll certainly find really good stuff from a style/show you like already
